text:
Is there a better way to do this:
```julia> const newdim = [CartesianIndex()]
1-element Array{CartesianIndex{0},1}:
 CartesianIndex()

julia> X = [1:2  3:4 5:6]
2×3 Array{Int64,2}:
 1  3  5
 2  4  6

julia> X .- @view X[:,newdim,:]
2×3×3 Array{Int64,3}:
[:, :, 1] =
 0  2  4
 0  2  4

[:, :, 2] =
 -2  0  2
 -2  0  2

[:, :, 3] =
 -4  -2  0
 -4  -2  0```

elements.text: Is there a better way to do this:

julia> const newdim = [CartesianIndex()]
1-element Array{CartesianIndex{0},1}:
 CartesianIndex()

julia> X = [1:2  3:4 5:6]
2×3 Array{Int64,2}:
 1  3  5
 2  4  6

julia> X .- @view X[:,newdim,:]
2×3×3 Array{Int64,3}:
[:, :, 1] =
 0  2  4
 0  2  4

[:, :, 2] =
 -2  0  2
 -2  0  2

[:, :, 3] =
 -4  -2  0
 -4  -2  0

attachments.title: How is numpy so fast?
attachments.text: I'm trying to understand how numpy can be so fast, based on my shocking comparison with optimized C/C++ code which is still far from reproducing numpy's speed. Consider the following example: Given...
attachments.fallback: Stack Overflow: How is numpy so fast?
